We provide a categorical definition of quantum theory. The definition is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. It is based on a small number of axioms that are satisfied by the category of Hilbert spaces and linear operators on them. The definition is therefore applicable to any consistent formulation of quantum theory. We show that the definition is equivalent to the standard axiomatizations of quantum theory in terms of states, observables, and measurements. We also show that the definition is equivalent to the standard axiomatizations in terms of the density matrix and Hermitian operators. This provides a new proof of the equivalence of the density matrix formulation with the operator-algebraic formulation.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are of great interest to the scientific community because of their extreme reduction in gene content and body plan. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results show that myxozoans are a sister group to the cnidarians, that they have one of the smallest animal genomes, and that they have undergone a remarkable reduction in gene content and body plan. These results provide insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is one of the most important strategies used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may help in the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1 channels, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change will increase the variability of global crop yields, making it more difficult to meet the world’s food demand. We quantify the magnitude of this yield variability and its consequences for global maize production and trade. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. Our results highlight the need for urgent investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in ecosystems worldwide. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify diet composition at the species level, and that this approach can be used to show that the degree of diet overlap is not always a good predictor of the degree of dietary similarity. Our results suggest that the degree of diet overlap may be less important than previously thought in determining coexistence in LMH assemblages. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the role of LMH in shaping ecosystems. Our results also suggest that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This is an important finding for the conservation of LMH and their ecosystems.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, and the majority plan to seek funding through the CARES Act. However, many anticipate problems accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility. Our results suggest that the CARES Act will be critical to supporting the survival of small businesses, but that the program will need to be improved to do so.

Plastic debris is a ubiquitous problem in the open ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important unsolved problems in astronomy. The solar system is thought to have formed from the aggregation of dust grains in the interstellar medium. The age of the solar system is estimated to be ∼4.6 Ga. However, the age of the grains that formed the solar system is unknown. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison meteorite.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In humans, it is the defining characteristic of the species Homo sapiens. In other species, reproduction is a secondary trait, and the ability to reproduce is not the defining characteristic of the species. In these species, the ability to reproduce is limited by factors other than the ability to reproduce. We show that the ability to reproduce is limited by maternal metabolic power in placental mammals.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in the brain of mice with MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a hallmark of MSA pathology. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This is the first proof of concept that a drug that is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy is able to slow down the progression of MSA in a mouse model. This opens the door for a phase I trial in MSA patients.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues, controls the contractility of the blood vessels, and controls hemostasis. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells, and each cell is specialized to perform a specific function. This paper describes the nature of the communication system between the cells of the endothelium. The communication system is highly efficient, with short path lengths and high synchronizability. The communication system is also scale-free, meaning that the number of connections between cells is not evenly distributed but rather follows a power law. The communication system is effective in both local and global communication, and it is robust and fast. The communication system is a key element in the control of cardiovascular activity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modelers. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We provide examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers and policy makers in the United States and beyond.

The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel’s pore and is the site of ion conduction. The selectivity filter is also the site of the activation gate, which is the gatekeeper of the channel’s selectivity filter. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for the functional and structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have shown that this residue is essential for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic ecosystem that is influenced by the host and its environment. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. We show that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, and that these natural products are produced in significant quantities. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to manipulate the composition of the gut microbiome.

Anxiety is a common feature of human social life and is associated with a variety of social disorders. Here we show that anxiety influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the current design paradigm is limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of the structures. Here, we propose a synthesis and fabrication strategy to design and fabricate composite structures with multiple material phases, which are digitally synthesized to achieve specific target behaviors. The synthesized structures are experimentally demonstrated to exhibit complex and programmable behaviors, which are unachievable by a single material. The proposed synthesis and fabrication strategy can be extended to design and fabricate structures with different materials and properties, which can be assembled into architectures to achieve highly complex behaviors. The proposed strategy can be applied to design and fabricate mechanical devices with programmable behaviors for a wide range of applications. This work can also be extended to design and fabricate structures with complex and programmable behaviors in other fields. The hemoglobin system is a key example of a developmental system that is regulated by the circadian clock. In this study, we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, which is a component of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway, is expressed in the erythroid lineage and plays a role in the chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. It is a relatively new form of cell death, and its role in cancer is not well understood. In this study, we found that the mutation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that this resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-dependent lipogenesis. In addition, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings provide insights into the role of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis in cancer and suggest a potential therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Our study shows that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension. Our findings also suggest that LCCBs may be used as a therapeutic target for the treatment of cardiovascular remodeling. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral bird populations, but the decline of older-forest–associated species accelerated. The NWFP was not effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations because of the continued loss of older forests due to fire and clearcutting elsewhere. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy, and our findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the plan.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate was tested in vitro and in vivo, and showed activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train and apply the networks in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We believe that this architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems in the future.

The Lake Malawi region is one of the most diverse freshwater ecosystems on Earth, and the lake has been shaped by dramatic changes in its size and shape over the past 1.3 My. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind record of the hydroclimate of the tropics, which shows that the region was drier than today before 800,000 years ago and wetter since. This shift in hydroclimate coincides with a change in the orbital forcing of climate, suggesting that the orbital forcing of climate is not the only factor controlling the evolution of this ecosystem.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice is associated with reduced sleep duration and quality, and with adverse consequences on general health. The mechanisms underlying the negative impact of electronic devices on sleep are not known, but it is likely that the short-wavelength–enriched light emitted by these devices is a contributing factor. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin secretion, reduces sleepiness, and phase-delays the circadian clock, thereby reducing sleep quality. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. They also provide a rationale for the development of electronic books that emit less light in the blue wavelength range. This is an important step toward improving the quality of sleep and health. The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known climate event that occurred 11.9–12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) in the YDB samples is likely terrestrial in origin, and that the bolide impact at 12.9 ka contributed to the cooling.

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the maintenance of immunological tolerance is still not fully understood. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in a variety of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the role of CTLA-4 in the maintenance of immunological tolerance is not limited to the early phase of T cell activation.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Our results show that beetles diversified in the presence of angiosperms, and that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers were key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. These results suggest that beetles diversified in a manner similar to other herbivorous insects, and that the evolution of specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring, was driven by convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding cell wall-degrading enzymes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be used to identify CDR changes that can alleviate the impact of mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to accelerate the development of new therapeutics to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary biologists and cultural ecologists. In this paper, we report the results of a large-scale experiment that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We show that, contrary to popular belief, population size does not enhance CCE. This finding has important implications for the evolution of culture and the emergence of technology. It also has implications for the design of experiments that investigate the role of culture in the emergence of technology. Finally, it has implications for the design of interventions that aim to enhance the cultural evolution of technology.

APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE4 is the most strongly associated allele. APOE is also a major protein of the classical complement pathway, which is known to be involved in AD pathology. Here, we show that APOE isoform is highly associated with the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is a process that is known to be important for normal brain function and is also known to be enhanced by APOE2. These studies suggest that APOE4 may be associated with AD risk in part because of defective synapse pruning by astrocytes. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that APOE4 is associated with increased accumulation of complement-coated senescent synapses in the brain. These studies also suggest that APOE may be a therapeutic target for AD treatment.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. In this study, we show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be two-step, with the first step being the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. They also provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that the brain responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are attenuated in marijuana abusers, who also show higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings suggest that the attenuated brain responses to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors and negative emotionality.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the brain’s processing of language is a central focus of neuroscience. However, the brain’s language system is not a single structure or process, but rather a network of many interacting systems. How this network is organized, and how it is shaped by experience, is not well understood. Here, we show that deep learning models, which are trained to predict a next word from a sentence, are able to predict neural and behavioral responses to sentences in the human brain. This suggests that the language system in the brain is shaped by predictive processing. These results provide a new perspective on the organization of the language system in the brain. They also provide a computational framework for future studies of the language system in the brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. In this paper, we show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that many problems in scientific computing are well-conditioned, meaning that there exist algorithms that can compute stable solutions. We introduce a new class of algorithms, called fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which are stable and converge fast. We prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a classification theory for the existence of algorithms that compute stable NNs in scientific computing. We believe that this theory will be useful for the development of DL in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a case study in the dangers of overreliance on flawed research. The classic experiment used to demonstrate the power of exponential growth is a case in point. It is cited by scientists as a key piece of evidence for the pandemic’s exponential growth. Yet, it is also a classic example of a flawed experiment. This article discusses the experiment’s design flaws, the implications for the study’s interpretation, and the need to critically assess the research that is used to support scientific claims.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and it is still a major public health problem in many parts of the world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for decades, but the cause of the other form of leprosy, which is associated with a reactional state known as lepromatous leprosy, has remained a mystery. We have sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, which is the causative agent of lepromatous leprosy, and compared it with that of M. leprae, which is the causative agent of lepromatous leprosy. Our results suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of the leprosy pathogen. (Show more)

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics of the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is a direct consequence of integrability and, thus, holds for a large class of interacting systems. We check our result for the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the most challenging regime for the exact computation of the entanglement dynamics.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The development of a safe and effective vaccine is the most effective way to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is safe and effective in a relevant animal model. This vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture on a large scale, which is critical for mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was characterized by recurrent epidemics and high mortality. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that it was spread by rats. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits the mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-mediated transmission in the history of infectious diseases. Our results have implications for the control of the disease today.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in the study of animal cognition. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only dependent on brain size but also on the number of neurons. This study shows that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells, and they are constantly disassembled and reassembled. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family is the central regulator of actin filament disassembly. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we monitor and quantify the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations by using single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension surprisingly has no effect on cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We propose that this ADF/cofilin-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. A consequence of this mechanism, which we verify experimentally, is that cross-linked filament networks are severed by cofilin far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is located ∼400 km from the coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar and found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, but the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island suggests that the settlement was not homogeneous. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the settlement history of Madagascar and the genetic diversity of the island. It also provides a new approach to study the settlement history of other islands. This approach can be applied to other islands and to other parts of the world.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others in social networks. This is a major finding, because it suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not interacting with those others in person. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social networks, for the spread of misinformation, and for the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions. It also suggests that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNA sequences can be modified after transcription, and these modifications can have important effects on the translation of the mRNA. We show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings have implications for the function of mRNA modifications and the translation machinery. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This study provides a deeper understanding of the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this sense of worthwhile living is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. These associations are robust to the effects of factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and health. Longitudinal analyses indicate that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is a strong predictor of positive outcomes over time. This finding suggests that the sense of worthwhile living may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and sustaining optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a long-standing puzzle. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of rhinovirus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature is a key factor in the pathogenesis of the common cold. Here, we show that this temperature-dependent growth phenotype is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and therapeutics.

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect contact with surfaces. This mechanochemical system is essential for the pathogen to adhere to surfaces, and it is also required for the activation of a number of virulence factors. Our results demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This finding provides a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria sense their environment and highlights the importance of type IV pili in bacterial pathogenesis.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in wildlife is a major concern for the long-term sustainability of the pandemic. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living and captive white-tailed deer in Iowa, USA. We show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer, and that the virus is transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our results also have implications for the management of wildlife in the context of the pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. The paper examines the problems and proposes solutions. The problems are that the benefits are overestimated and the costs are underestimated. The solutions are to incorporate climate change into the decision-making process, to consider the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned, and to use innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. The exact mechanisms underlying the development of these pathologies are not fully understood, but it is clear that they are intimately linked. In this study, we show that soluble Aβ is toxic to neurons, and that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is a key factor in the development of a proinflammatory response. This response is not observed in glial cells, suggesting that the neuron is the primary source of inflammation in AD. Our findings provide a new perspective on the pathogenesis of AD, and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the study of the evolution of animal husbandry and the spread of agriculture. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. The present work shows that the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, proceeds through distinct steps, the first of which is a native-like intermediate. This is the first time that such a step has been observed in a large protein. The results suggest that the folding of proteins is more complex than previously thought.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they are capped at their 5′ ends with a nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) cap, which is required for their function in inhibiting translation. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the Np4 cap is also capable of removing the cap from dinucleoside triphosphates, which are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. This finding has implications for the function of alarmones in bacteria, as well as for the design of synthetic systems that can be used to control the expression of genes in response to stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. Although there are several therapeutic strategies for sepsis, there is no specific treatment that can restore immune function after sepsis. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore immune function and decrease immunosuppression after sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, was more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression in a mouse model of sepsis. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a new therapeutic strategy for sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This information is essential for the development of sustainable practices and policies.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems with no external control parameter oscillate between two or more distinct states. SOC systems are characterized by the fact that the rate of change of the system state is proportional to the current system state. This paper is about a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the classical sandpile model. We show that the model exhibits a rich variety of dynamical behaviors, including a scaling limit with a power-law decay of correlations. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, sensors, and quantum devices. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity, which limits its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This opens up a new avenue for tailoring the properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The discovery of a large number of nodule-specific cysteine-rich peptides in the model legume Medicago truncatula has opened up a new avenue for the discovery of bioactive peptides. However, there is a lack of knowledge regarding their structural architecture, antifungal activity, and modes of action against plant fungal pathogens. Here, we report the solution structure of the 36-amino acid NCR044 peptide, its antifungal activity, and its mode of action against plant fungal pathogens. Our work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work also provides a structural basis for the mode of action of this peptide against plant fungal pathogens. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the life history of sperm is intimately linked to the female reproductive tract. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become enriched in the sperm proteome after mating, suggesting that they support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular mechanisms that underlie the male–female interface. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large, multidomain protein that binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) to promote platelet adhesion and coagulation. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD), and gain-of-function mutations in VWF have been used to study the mechanism of action of VWF. We show that force application switches VWF from a low-force to a high-force state, providing a mechanism for the action of VWD mutations. The mechanism of action of VWD mutations is explained by the conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways. This approach provides a simple and powerful way to study the mechanism of action of proteins. It is expected to be useful for other proteins and may be of general interest.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microorganisms that has been shown to influence health. However, the human virome has been difficult to study, and the number of studies that have attempted to do so is small. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, which will allow for the study of the role of viruses in human health. The resource is available for download, and is searchable via a web interface.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes, such as the influence of aerosols on water cloud droplet formation. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct continuous observations of aerosols and clouds over Beijing, China. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of great interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the evolution of life on the planet. In this paper, we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past.

K+ channels are the most abundant ion channels in the body and are important for the regulation of many physiological processes. The K+ channel KCNQ1 has been implicated in the pathogenesis of cardiac arrhythmia. The K+ channel BK is a large-conductance, calcium-activated K+ channel that is important for the regulation of blood pressure. The BK channel is unique in that it lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. These findings provide insights into the mechanism of K+ channel regulation. They also suggest that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This may be important for the development of drugs that can selectively target the BK channel. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide and is caused by the Plasmodium parasite. The parasite must overcome a number of barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC) and begin its replication within the cell. Here, we show that the malaria parasite exploits the physical properties of the RBC to facilitate invasion. We show that the binding of the parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 to glycophorin A on the RBC surface leads to an increase in the tension of the RBC cytoskeleton and a reduction in the bending modulus of the membrane. These changes in the RBC are correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This work suggests that the malaria parasite primes the RBC surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work has important implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, optics, and photonics. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. Therefore, it is not easy to use it in applications that require large deformation. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, i.e., its bandgap can be closed, without phonon instability. This opens up new opportunities for diamond applications in mechanical engineering, electronics, optics, and photonics.

The impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases the severity of influenza virus infection. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection and may help to develop strategies to mitigate the impact of dry air on influenza disease. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the brain’s activity during the construction of such a tree remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a neural implementation of a merge operation, which applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the brain’s language system.

Wnt signaling is a major pathway in development and homeostasis. Axin is a scaffold that converts signals at the plasma membrane to signals that inhibit the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. We show that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms of redundant genes and their regulation. It also provides a model for the study of redundant genes in other organisms. This work may also have implications for the development of therapeutics for cancer and other diseases.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a hypothalamic nucleus that is important for feeding. We have identified a circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit is located in the LH and is composed of neurons that project to the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr). Stimulation of this circuit in the LH causes animals to eat more than normal. This circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen (N2) from the atmosphere is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle and is essential for the growth of all terrestrial plants. However, the amount of N2 fixed by plants is far less than the amount fixed by the estimated 100 trillion bacteria that live in the soil. Thus, there is a need to develop strategies to increase the efficiency of N2 fixation in the soil. Here, we demonstrate a strategy to control the symbiotic interaction between plants and bacteria, which fix N2 in the soil.

Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate deforestation. However, the effectiveness of these systems in deterring deforestation is unknown. We study a community-based monitoring program that was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities in the Peruvian Amazon. Our results suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. Our results also suggest that the effectiveness of these systems is contingent on the ability of the community to detect and respond to deforestation in a timely manner.

The spider is a model organism for studying the evolution of sensory systems and the mechanisms of sensory transduction. Here, we show that the spider can sense sound by sensing the motion of its web, which acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider’s web is a self-manufactured, protein-based material that is not constrained by the organism’s body size. The spider can increase its surface area by 10,000 times, which is much larger than the spider itself. This provides a unique feature for studying the sensing of fluid dynamics and the regeneration of the external acoustic sensor. The spider’s acoustic outsourcing and supersizing provides insights into the evolution of sensory systems and the mechanisms of sensory transduction. The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic emissions are difficult to disentangle. We show that removing fossil-fuel-related emissions reduces the number of excess deaths by 3.6 million per year, and aerosols by 1.8 million per year, thus reducing the total number of deaths by 5.5 million per year. This is a substantial fraction of the 5.5 million deaths per year from air pollution. The reduction of aerosols also restores rainfall patterns, which are perturbed by aerosols, and reduces the number of excess deaths by 1.2 million per year. The combined effect of removing fossil-fuel-related emissions and aerosols is to reduce the number of excess deaths by 6.7 million per year, which is about 10% of the 65 million deaths per year from air pollution.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has killed over 500,000 people in the United States alone. The lack of a vaccine has been a major obstacle to containing the pandemic. Here we report the design and characterization of a recombinant protein subunit vaccine candidate that can be produced in large quantities and is capable of inducing high levels of neutralizing antibodies. This vaccine candidate is based on a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that mediates viral entry into cells. The variant is engineered to be manufacturable at high yields, to bind to the ACE2 receptor with high affinity, and to be immunogenic. The vaccine candidate can be presented on a virus-like particle, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This vaccine candidate is a potential candidate for global deployment. The development of neural crest-derived tissues is a complex process involving multiple signaling pathways. Here, we show that the zebrafish homolog of the ALK/Ltk receptor tyrosine kinase is activated by secreted ALKAL proteins. We demonstrate that the ALKALs are potent activators of the zebrafish ALK/Ltk receptor and that the ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, a neural crest-derived tissue. Our results provide evidence for a role of ALKALs in neural crest development and suggest that ALKALs may be attractive targets for the treatment of neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague, the deadliest pathogen in human history, is a topic of great interest to the scientific community. The study of ancient pathogens has been hindered by the scarcity of ancient DNA evidence, but recent advances in ancient DNA recovery and sequencing have allowed us to explore the origins of plague in a way that was not possible before. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from across Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during its formative years. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. These data provide a more complete picture of the early evolution and ecology of plague, and may have implications for the spread of the pathogen in the past and in the future. (Less)

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support

The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has released a large amount of carbon to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of grasslands can mitigate this release and that the management of croplands can accelerate the release of carbon to the atmosphere. The results of this study have important implications for the design of climate-smart agricultural systems. The results also highlight the importance of grasslands in the global carbon cycle.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 zoonotic viruses, which are known SARS-CoV-2 and other viruses. We also identified 100+ viruses that are at high risk of spillover and spread to humans. We hope that this work will inform the development of strategies to prevent future spillover events and mitigate the impact of future outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinators to locate flowers, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of nectar in Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We demonstrate that this alkaloid is attractive to the vertebrate pollinator, Phelsuma geckos, and that this trait is convergent in two other species of plants visited by hummingbirds. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is likely to be favored in nectar-feeding animals.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men from this region is similar to that of modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestries of women are very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we show that women from this region differed in visible characteristics, which were associated with their genetic ancestry. Finally, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. Our results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. These results also establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. Our findings are important for understanding the evolution of coronaviruses and for developing strategies to prevent their cross-species transmission. (Show more)

The lagging strand of the double helix is synthesized by the enzyme DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells. This process is essential for the survival of the cell and the organism. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical for the synthesis of the lagging strand, but the exact nature of this stability is unknown. We developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme is loose and dissociates from PCNA during DNA synthesis. This behavior has profound implications for the synthesis of the lagging strand in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the replication of RNA by an RNA polymerase ribozyme. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvement, (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances are more likely to experience improvement, and (iii) neighborhoods that are physically proximate to attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvement. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new method for monitoring the physical changes in cities over time. This method can be used to monitor the effects of urban policy and to study the physical dynamics of cities. We hope that this method will be useful for urban scholars and practitioners.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that the patients with severe and critical COVID-19 had high levels of interleukin 6, which may be the cause of the inflammatory storm. Tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6, was given to the patients, and the results showed that it could improve the clinical symptoms and reduce mortality.

Copper homeostasis is a critical component of fungal physiology, and the mechanisms by which fungi maintain copper at appropriate levels are not well understood. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC, which encodes isocyanide products of the xan biosynthetic gene cluster, is present in several filamentous fungi, and that these products bind copper. We show that xanthocillin-derived isocyanide products have antimicrobial properties, and that copper is required for their activity. These results suggest that the xan BGC is involved in the maintenance of copper homeostasis, and that the isocyanide products of the xan BGC may be involved in interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the maintenance of copper homeostasis and the regulation of interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, which are the world’s largest carbon sinks. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that the resistance strategies of trees are also changing accordingly. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a heterogeneous subset of CD4+ T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of certain inflammatory bowel diseases. However, the developmental origins of these cells are unknown. Here we show that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have important implications for the development of novel therapies for inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the cells responsible for sending signals from the brain and spinal cord to the muscles. We have developed a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This method now enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will accelerate ALS research and development of therapeutics. This method will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases. This method will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of arthropods is an important component of their immune system and plays a role in the transmission of pathogens. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the tick to produce antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. These data provide a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen can influence the microbiota of its vector to enhance transmission. This work also highlights the potential for pathogens to manipulate the microbiota of their vectors to enhance transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of vertebrates. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is still controversial. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan and the mosaic evolution of the avian body plan.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, including blue-green. This phenomenon, called chlorosis, is associated with high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally present in animals only in the liver. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times in frogs and toads, and that the mechanism is the same—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. We also show that these proteins are most similar to human antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results provide molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of color in vertebrates and the function of serpins. They also have implications for the biology of frogs and toads, which are among the most abundant vertebrates on Earth.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and is associated with the maintenance of the stem cell phenotype. We show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates m6A in the NANOG mRNA 3′-UTR. This results in increased NANOG mRNA and protein levels, and the maintenance of the stem cell phenotype. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. This paper reports on a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to extract protein from the parchment surface, followed by analysis of the extracted protein by mass spectrometry. The method is noninvasive and can be used to analyze a large number of samples.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. In this study, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs, which is associated with corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. These findings suggest that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for vaccine development and the focus of much attention in the scientific community. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2. We show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation that may facilitate binding to the receptor. This work provides a better understanding of the structure of the spike protein and may help to inform the design of future vaccines. (Show more)

We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate the impact of COVID-19 on life expectancy in the United States in 2020, by race and ethnicity, and project the impact of COVID-19 on life expectancy in the United States in 2020, by race and ethnicity. Our projections imply that the Black−White life expectancy gap will increase by nearly 40%.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the key to understanding the properties of matter. In this paper, we show that pressure can change the chemical properties of atoms, and that these properties can be used to predict and explain the properties of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of fires, but the implications for the carbon cycle are uncertain. We show that human ignitions and suppression can have a strong influence on fire regimes, and that this can have a large impact on the carbon cycle. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowing the rate of warming, but that this effect is uncertain and depends on the future trajectory of human demography. Our results also highlight the importance of active fire management in reducing the risk of more extreme fires in the future.
