The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Our results have important implications for the understanding of the spread of the plague in Europe and for the development of the theory of the “plague rats.” Our findings also have implications for the spread of pathogens in general.

Asteroids are a group of marine invertebrates that are of great importance to the ecosystem. They are a food source for many species of fish and seabirds, and they are also a part of the food web for humans. In the past few years, a disease has been observed in populations of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. The disease is characterized by rapid death, loss of turgor, and lesions on the body. We show that the disease is caused by a virus. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. The identification of targets for the treatment of AML is therefore of great importance. We show here that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that the antibody can be used to treat primary human AML cells in vitro and in vivo. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the antibody can be used to treat other diseases in which IL1RAP is expressed. Thus, IL1RAP can be considered as a target for antibody-based treatment of a variety of diseases. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The settlement history of Madagascar is still debated, and we provide a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of the Malagasy population. We show that Madagascar was settled by a population that was already admixed, and that the settlement happened in a sex-biased manner, with a higher contribution of men from Southeast Asia. These results provide a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar and its consequences on the present genomic diversity. They also provide a better understanding of the human population dynamics and the human colonization of Madagascar.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be mediated by the brain’s language network. In this work, we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that memory is maintained through adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is distinct from the conventional view of memory as being based on sustained, elevated neural activity. Our model provides a neurobiological substrate for the binding of linguistic features over time and the maintenance of information in working memory. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great scientific interest. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The origin of the plastid genome and its evolution are key to understanding the evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of life. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of plants, and the molecular signature of this transition is not known. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the drought by a factor of five to six. This finding is important for the policy makers in SSA, as it highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk to future emissions. Our results also show that the drought risk will increase substantially in the future, even under a low-emission scenario. This highlights the need for urgent adaptation measures. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is one of the most important reactions in photosynthesis. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, which have remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. Here, we show that the two enzymes are members of a family of proteins that are conserved in plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also a hallmark of multiple sclerosis (MS), the most common chronic inflammatory disease of the CNS. In this study, we found that ASK1, a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, is involved in neuroinflammation. We also found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater proinflammatory role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We show that the probability of drought has increased in California over the past century, and that this increase is attributable to anthropogenic warming. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we show that behavioral flexibility, which is a measure of the ability to forget, is a converging target of the autism-risk genes. This finding suggests that the inability to forget is a common mechanism underlying the autism spectrum disorders.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, but its physiological role has remained elusive. Here, we show that loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. We also identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1 that, in mice, result in spontaneous bleeding accompanied by reduced numbers of thrombocytes. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we use a Drosophila model to demonstrate that protein aggregates spread in a transcellular manner, and that this spreading is dependent on the internalization of aggregates. We also show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on the fusion of synaptic vesicles with lysosomes, and that this is required for the spread of aggregates. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in the brain, and may help to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not fully understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats and demonstrated that this protein is a potent immunosuppressant that facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Our findings also highlight the importance of understanding the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats and the potential for therapeutic intervention. This study may also contribute to the development of a better understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses and the development of therapeutic strategies to prevent the emergence of zoonotic viruses. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that they are effective cellular target engagement. We also show that formate generally rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We demonstrate that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These results provide a foundation for the development of a therapeutic strategy for cancer patients with defective one-carbon unit metabolism. This strategy is particularly attractive for patients with lymphoma, who are at high risk for resistance to chemotherapy. Our findings also suggest that SHMT inhibition may be a viable strategy for the treatment of other diseases that are dependent upon one-carbon unit metabolism. Thus, SHMT inhibition may be a promising therapeutic target for cancer and other diseases.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results provide a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The device is expected to be scalable to larger dimensions. This work opens up a new platform for studying many-body physics with neutral atoms. It also provides a promising approach for engineering exotic quantum matter in 2D and beyond. (Show more)

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The first flowering plants were aquatic, and the discovery of Montsechia, a new genus and species of early flowering plant, opens up the possibility that aquatic plants were common at the very beginning of the evolution of the flowering plants.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in providing a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of a key enzyme intermediate. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed picture of enzyme mechanisms, and it provides a model for how this approach can be applied to other enzymes and reaction types.

There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease emphasizes the need for effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, and the most common reason for suspension is misbehavior. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline, and that this change can reduce suspension rates. The study also shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships and students’ respect for teachers are important predictors of whether students will be suspended. These findings have implications for policy and practice, and for the development of scalable interventions.

Alkylated DNA lesions, induced by both exogenous chemical agents and endogenous metabolites, are known to interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this work, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis. We found that the stalling of RNA polymerase II at alkylated DNA lesions is strongly favored for the minor-groove alkylated DNA lesions. In contrast, the major-groove alkylated DNA lesions are prone to GMP misincorporation. Furthermore, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II, termed Pro-Gate loop, which is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings are expected to provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional mutagenesis and mutagenesis in general. This work also provides a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional mutagenesis and mutagenesis in general.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus spike (S) glycoproteins. We found that these mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Therefore, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food choices of the world’s wealthiest people have a disproportionate impact on the environment and population health. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of people choosing vegetarian meals by 40%. This is a simple and scalable intervention that could be implemented in a wide range of settings. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings could have a significant impact on the environment and population health. The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to measure the surface proteome of cells, and have applied it to characterize the surfaceome of a panel of oncogenic breast epithelial cells. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a framework for understanding the cell surface proteome in the context of oncogenesis. It also provides a platform for the study of other systems, such as cancer metastasis, in which the cell surface is a key interface.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings also suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that it is unlikely to have significant effects on electoral outcomes.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the molecular basis of viral pathogenesis. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV. This structure provides insight into the molecular basis of the unique immune evasion and evasion of the host innate immune response activities of SARS-CoV-2. These activities may be mediated by the unique dimerization interface, which may be important for the formation of large-scale assemblies. This work provides a better understanding of the molecular basis of the COVID-19 disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. It also provides a foundation for the development of vaccines and therapeutics that target this virus. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex, which in turn leads to edema. These findings provide a molecular mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. This knowledge may be useful for the development of new therapies for the treatment of cerebral edema. We live in an age of big data. The amount of data that we collect is growing exponentially. The statistical methods that we use to analyze these data are also growing exponentially. This paper describes a new challenge that arises in this context. We have a large dataset and we want to find the strongest associations in it. The fact that we have “cherry-picked” the dataset means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this paper will stimulate further research in this exciting area.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the generation of endothelial cells from fibroblasts. This finding provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. Furthermore, the generation of ETVECs provides a model for studying the development of ECs and may be useful for the treatment of ischemic disorders. The discovery of ligand-activated RTKs has opened up a new field of research that has led to the identification of a large number of ligands and their receptors. In this study, we show that augmentor ligands are ligands of the orphan receptors anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We also show that augmentor ligands are essential for zebrafish iridophore patterning. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that augmentor ligands are important for the development of a particular type of sensory cells in zebrafish. This work provides a new perspective on the function of orphan RTKs and their ligands. It also provides a model system for the study of a particular type of sensory cell in zebrafish. This work may also have implications for the development of cancer therapies.

The role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been well established. However, its function in β-cell is still unknown. Influenza A viruses are the most pathogenic viruses known to date. They cause annual epidemics and occasional pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is a potential advantage for the virus to adapt to new hosts. However, it also complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the interaction between viral RNA segments is a molecular mechanism that is used by the influenza A virus to promote the selective packaging of its genome.

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is associated with the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The disturbed flow, a key feature of atherosclerosis, is associated with the activation of YAP/TAZ, which is a key transcription factor in mediating vascular homeostasis. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerosis and suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a rationale for the development of athero-protective strategies based on the inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the frequency and intensity of wildfires has increased dramatically in recent decades, and is now a major threat to the health and safety of people and the environment. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the role of humans in increasing wildfire activity in the United States. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that human-caused fires are disproportionately concentrated in areas where people live and work. These findings highlight the need for a better understanding of the causes of wildfire, and for actions to reduce the risk of wildfire to people and the environment.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a group of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insects. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods are still unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which is absent in insects. This study provides a new perspective on the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods. It also contributes to the conservation of biodiversity and the rational design of insect control strategy. This work may also help to understand the evolution of the arthropod–plant interaction. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the virus in the pathogenesis of the disease is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid rise in viremia, the short eclipse phase, and the rapid clearance of the virus. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment on the disease course. The model can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials and to assess the impact of control measures. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is associated with the breakdown of the symbiotic relationship between corals and their algal partners. However, the underlying causes of bleaching are still not fully understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to better predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also a hub for communication with the microbiome. We show that the microbiome can influence the growth of intestinal tumors and that the tumor can influence the microbiome. We also show that the microbiome can influence the activity of the intestinal epithelium, and that the activity of the epithelium can influence the microbiome. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of the intestinal epithelium to maintain homeostasis between the host and its microbiome. This work also provides a model for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer progression. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. We show that the expression of the ROR1 receptor is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhances the invasive and metastatic properties of breast cancer cells. We also show that the anti-ROR1 antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, and that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with cirmtuzumab and chemotherapy is more effective than treatment with either alone. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. Thus, ROR1 may be a promising target for the treatment of breast cancer. The timing of the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most debated aspects of the last deglaciation. Here, we show that the onset of deglaciation is linked to a series of volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and marked climate changes.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in assessments of global biodiversity and ecosystem services. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, particularly in regions where alternative sources of nutrition and employment are scarce. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to identify areas where fisheries are most likely to contribute to food security while also protecting biodiversity. This approach can help to ensure that the benefits of rivers and lakes are not overlooked in environmental planning.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery provides a unique platform for the discovery of novel genes involved in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate after injury is not limited to the nervous system.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, which are necessary for sexual reproduction. In flowering plants, meiosis is a complex process that involves the formation of chiasmata, which are bridges between homologous chromosomes. The process of chiasma formation is highly variable across the genome, and it is important to understand the factors that influence the rate of chiasma formation. Here, we describe the distribution of chiasma formation in the wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that the distribution of chiasma formation is highly variable across the genome, and that the distribution of chiasma formation is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice. This suggests that the distribution of chiasma formation in plants may be conserved across evolution.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis has been proposed to explain the organization of the brain’s functional architecture. This hypothesis has been validated in healthy subjects, but its validity in disease populations has not been established. We used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN was similar to the default mode network in healthy subjects. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and task performance in PD patients. This abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is found on all mRNAs that are translated in yeast. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that NAD-mRNA is produced cotranscriptionally and that it is required for efficient translation. These results suggest that the NAD-cap could modulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery broadens our understanding of the diversity of 5′ modifications and their potential roles in mRNA function.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up of people with diabetes, and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a potential epigenetic mechanism for the beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of epigenetic biomarkers and therapeutic targets for diabetes.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that affects the brain and the gut. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier dysfunction and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence. View Full-Text

The flavor of tomato fruit is largely determined by the volatile chemicals it produces during ripening. These chemicals are produced by a variety of metabolic pathways, including the biosynthesis of nitrogenous compounds. The contribution of nitrogenous compounds to the flavor of tomato fruit is not well understood, and the sources of these compounds are unknown. Here, we identify a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. It also provides a model for the study of nitrogenous volatile biosynthesis in tomato and other species of the tomato clade. This work will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. (Show more)

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are exacerbated by biodiversity loss. This result is driven by two processes: (i) the increased probability of including species with thermal traits that maintain ecosystem functioning under environmental warming; and (ii) the increased importance of complementarity in maintaining ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for predicting the impacts of climate change on the functioning of natural ecosystems and the services they provide to society.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to reflect different aspects of the environment. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice, and we found that grid cells, which are thought to encode the spatial layout of the environment, are anatomically distinct from other cell types. These data provide a more complete picture of the organization of MEC neurons and will be useful for understanding the function of MEC in navigation. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for the flowering of the host and the parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering in plants. It is likely that the flowering signal FT is a common signal in plants, which may be used by plants to synchronize their flowering with that of their hosts. This may be an important mechanism for the synchronization of flowering in plants.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra, the classical site of dopamine synthesis, receive input from striatonigral fibers that originate in the striatum. These fibers form bouquet-like arborizations that target clusters of dopamine-containing neurons and also project to the striatum. Thus, the striatonigral fibers form a subsystem of the nigro–striato–nigral loop that is critical to dopamine-related function. Given the role of striosomes in mood and motivation, the striatonigral fibers and their bouquet-like arborizations could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are often asked, “Do you and [person you’re interested in] click?” We show that the answer to this question is not only “yes” or “no” but also “how much.” We show that the speed with which two people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of how connected they feel to each other. This signal is used by people to gauge the quality of their relationships, and it is used by third-party listeners to gauge the quality of the relationship between two people.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate, and their function is tightly regulated by the internal Ca2+ store and the plasma membrane. However, the mechanisms that govern SAN function are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and plays a critical role in SAN function. STIM1 regulates SAN function by controlling the content of Ca2+ in the internal Ca2+ store and the activity of the plasma membrane. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapies for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its function in plant defense has not been well established. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by priming of the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the defense response to insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the function of Si in plant defense. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the metabolism of ether lipids in murine macrophages and that it is essential for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism and suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a highly complex system that is thought to be mediated by the brain. However, the neural basis of language is still poorly understood. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of synaptic plasticity. This idea is not new, but it has not been explored in the context of language. We show that this mechanism can support memory for a few words, and that it can be extended to support memory for longer periods of time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical area of research, as it is essential for the delivery of functional biomolecules such as siRNA to plants. Herein, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plants. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the plant biology and nanotechnology communities. (Show more)

The world’s largest lakes are often viewed as remote and distant from human activities, but this study shows that the nutrient inputs from small tributaries can be significant and can have a disproportionate impact on coastal ecosystems. Our results suggest that small tributaries may be a significant source of coastal eutrophication, especially in lakes that are highly vulnerable to algal blooms. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal nutrient inputs and the need for more comprehensive management efforts to address nutrient loading from all sources.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a small initial condition for the universe is required to explain the observed homogeneity and isotropy of the universe.

The mechanisms by which antibodies to the N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor disrupt receptor function and cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes in cortical microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We also show that the same changes in cortical microcircuitry can be tolerated in the absence of antibodies. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab and may help explain the diversity of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with this disorder. Our findings also suggest that the same microcircuitry that is susceptible to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities may also be susceptible to seizures. This may help explain the association between NMDAR-Ab encephalitis and epilepsy. Our findings may also help explain the association between NMDAR-Ab encephalitis and epilepsy. The history of carbon (C) perturbations throughout Earth’s history has been a key focus of the scientific community. However, the history of C perturbations during abrupt warming events has been less well understood. Here, we present a multiproxy approach to investigate a global warming event that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that the event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. The event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived C over a large area of the ocean floor and to anoxia. Modeling indicates that the event was linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and nutrient fluxes. Our results provide insights into the history of abrupt warming events and the potential for future climate change. (Less)

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduces deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that most of these reductions occur in plantations that are already small relative to the remaining forest. We also show that certification has no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the need for certification schemes to be more stringent in their requirements and to be accompanied by strong monitoring and enforcement. These results also highlight the need for a more holistic approach to reducing deforestation, which includes not only certification but also the development of alternative markets for sustainable palm oil.

The exocytosis process is essential for the transport of molecules from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane. The exocytosis process is regulated by the exocyst complex, which is composed of multiple subunits. The function of the exocyst complex is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. We discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocytosis process and offers a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles interact to produce the sex of an individual. In this study, we show that the interaction of multiple alleles can produce a modular system of secondary sexual characteristics, which can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species- and light-generated photoproducts of lipids. We show that the levels of iron in the retina, as reflected in the transferrin receptor, are important for the photooxidation and photodegradation of the retinal photopigment, A2E. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly.

Predator specialization is a fundamental process in ecology and evolution, but it is often considered a dead end due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophore specialists can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have directly evolved into specialists on other prey types. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. These findings are relevant to a wide range of fields, including ecology, evolution, and the history of life.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The fossil record for the evolution of the hand is fragmentary, and the earliest hominins are represented by only a few isolated bones. Here we report the discovery of a hand fossil from East Africa that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding has important implications for the evolution of the hand and the emergence of modern human form. (Show more)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic enzyme that converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We also show that a pyrazolopyran scaffold that inhibits plant SHMT is a potent inhibitor of SHMT1/2 in human cells. We further show that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell lines, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Our work provides a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in cancer therapy, and a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This work also provides a foundation for the design of more potent and selective SHMT inhibitors. (Show more)

The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with a growing number of people suffering from undernutrition as well as from micronutrient deficiencies. In this study, we show that deforestation can have negative consequences for people’s diets, particularly in terms of vitamin A adequacy. Our findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. Our results also highlight the need for a more holistic approach to food and nutrition security, which considers the role of natural landscapes in meeting food and nutrition goals. This is particularly important given the growing global population and the need to feed a growing number of people.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the weight of farm machinery now exceeding that of the largest animals that walked Earth. This has led to the compaction of the soil, which is now a major problem for agricultural productivity. We show that the compaction of the subsoil has become a widespread problem, with a large proportion of arable land at risk of losing productivity. We also show that the weight of modern farm machinery is now comparable to that of the largest animals that walked Earth, suggesting that the compaction of the subsoil may have been a problem for these prehistoric giants.
